By
Rolling Stone
Rolling Stone
Jack Danielâ€™s Presenta: â€˜Musicians on Musicians Latinoâ€™ with Myke Towers and Elena Rose
Lil Nas X, Ariana Grande, 21 Savage, And All the Songs You Need to Know This Week
Mardi Gras Unmasked: Charles DuVernay and the Black Masking Indians
View all posts by Rolling Stone
August 29, 2019
Michael Ochs Archives/Getty
â€˜Every Grain of Sandâ€™
Image Credit: Paul Natkin/WireImage
Shot of Love, 1981
â€œItâ€™s like one of the great Psalms of David,â€ Bono says about â€œEvery Grain of Sand,â€ the spellbinding ballad from Shot of Love that concludes Dylanâ€˜s overtly Christian songwriting phase. Equal parts Blakean mysticism and biblical resonance, the song abandons the self-righteousness that plagued Dylanâ€™s religious work to offer a desperate prayer for salvation. Shadowing Dylan on vocals is gospel great (and Dylan flame) Clydie King: â€œI get chills when I hear her just breathe,â€ Dylan said. â€œEvery Grain of Sandâ€ taps into a moving humility (â€œSometimes I turn, thereâ€™s someone there, other times itâ€™s only me,â€ he sings). As Bono puts it, â€œDylan stops wailing against the world, turns on himself and is brought to his knees.â€
Dylan later described â€œEvery Grain of Sandâ€ as â€œan inspired song that just came to meâ€¦. I felt like I was just putting words down that were coming from somewhere else.â€
RELATED:
â€¢ Bob Dylanâ€™s Greatest Collaborations
â€˜Visions of Johannaâ€™
Image Credit: Jan Persson/Redferns/Getty Images
â€˜Mr. Tambourine Manâ€™
Image Credit: Jeff Kravitz/FilmMagic, Inc
â€˜Itâ€™s Alright, Ma (Iâ€™m Only Bleeding)â€™
Image Credit: Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images
â€˜I Shall Be Releasedâ€™
Image Credit: Thomas Monaster/NY Daily News Archive via Getty Images
â€˜All Along the Watchtowerâ€™
Image Credit: Chris Wood/Express/Getty Images
â€˜Just Like a Womanâ€™
Image Credit: Fiona Adams/Redferns/Getty Images
Blonde On Blonde, 1966
Dylanâ€˜s finest ballad is not a love song. â€œJust Like a Womanâ€ is a complex portrait of adoration and disappointment, written as vengeance but sung as regret. Dylan never revealed a specific inspiration for the woman indicted. (Dylanologists often cite Andy Warholâ€™s star-crossed protÃ©gÃ©e Edie Sedgwick.) But the song is more about his own turbulent lessons in romance â€” the giving, taking and leaving. It is also Dylanâ€™s first great country-rock performance. Dylan was making thunder and headlines onstage that year with the Hawks, but he cut this song with Nashville session cats who heard and heightened his tangle of rapture and despair. â€œThereâ€™s a lifetime of listening in these details,â€ songwriter Jimmy Webb said. â€œI still marvel at what an absolutely stunning piece of writing it is.â€
RELATED:
â€¢ The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time: Blonde on Blonde
â€˜Tangled Up in Blueâ€™
Image Credit: Alvan Meyerowitz/Michael Ochs Archive/Getty
Blood On the Tracks, 1975
â€œ took me 10 years to live, and two years to write,â€ Dylan often said before playing â€œTangled Up in Blueâ€ in concert. His marriage was crumbling in 1974 as he wrote what would become the opener on Blood on the Tracks and his most personal examination of hurt and nostalgia. Dylanâ€™s lyrical shifts in perspective, between confession and critique, and his acute references to the Sixties experience evoked a decade of both utopian and broken promise. His plaintive vocal and the fresh-air picking of the Minneapolis session players, organized by his brother, David Zimmerman, hearkened to an earlier pathos: the frank heartbreak and spiritual restoration in Appalachian balladry. Dylan has played this song many different ways live but rarely strays from the perfect crossroads of this recording, where emotional truths meet the everlasting comfort of the American folk song.
RELATED:
â€¢ The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time: Blood on the Tracks
â€˜A Hard Rainâ€™s A-Gonna Fallâ€™
Image Credit: Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images
â€˜Like a Rolling Stoneâ€™
Image Credit: Photograph by Jerry Schatzberg/TrunkArchive.com
